summary: This is a memorandum filed by Ghislaine Maxwell's defense attorneys in support of her third motion for release on bail. It proposes two additional bail conditions: renouncing her French and British citizenship, and placing her and her spouse's assets under the monitoring of a retired federal judge. The document argues these conditions eliminate flight risk and criticizes the strength of the government's case.

events.title: Filing of Third Bail Motion
events.description: Ghislaine Maxwell files her third motion for release on bail, proposing new conditions.

keyFacts: Ghislaine Maxwell offers to renounce her French and British citizenship as a bail condition to eliminate concerns she might seek refuge in those countries.

Maxwell proposes placing her and her spouse's assets (except for legal fees and living expenses) in a new account monitored by retired federal judge William S. Duffey, Jr., who would have co-signing authority.

Maxwell's defense team has filed twelve pretrial motions challenging the indictment, including motions to dismiss based on a non-prosecution agreement, pre-indictment delay, and statute of limitations grounds.
The document argues Maxwell is an American citizen who has lived in the U.S. for 30 years, has strong family ties, and has no intention to flee, seeking only to prepare for trial.
The defense cites the case of Dominique Strauss-Kahn as a precedent where a foreign citizen facing serious charges was granted bail with conditions.
